At peak now–2025.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Cave de Tain 2017 Terroirs d'Exception Vieilles Vignes  (Saint-Joseph)

Description: Ripe but restrained mulberry and cassis take center stage in this fresh-fruited Syrah, but wisps of earthen granite, ore and smoke lend complexity, too. Plump and medium-bodied in style, it's a crisply balanced, unoaked red with a lingering mineral finish. At peak now–2024.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Pierre le Grand 2017  Crozes-Hermitage

Description: There's a reverberating granite undertone to pristine blackberry and plum flavors in this zesty, mineral Syrah. Made from 100% destemmed fruit and aged 12 months in oak (15% new), it offers a purity of cutting black fruit flavors and a long finish marked by firm, gripping tannins. At peak now–2026.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Éric & Jöel Durand 2016 Les Coteaux  (Saint-Joseph)

Description: Intensely ripe blackberry and cassis are shaded by hints of smoke and char in this ripe but elegantly restrained red. Produced with 95% destemmed fruit, it's fruit profile is pure and pristine, accented by just a whisper of spice. Youthful fruit and fine, silky tannins are at peak now but should hold through 2027.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Domaine Boissonnet 2017 Emisphère Rouge  (Saint-Joseph)

Description: Ripe but restrained mulberry and cassis take center stage in this fresh-fruited Syrah, but wisps of earthen granite, ore and smoke lend complexity, too. Plump and medium-bodied in style, it's a crisply balanced, unoaked red with a lingering mineral finish. At peak now–2024.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Pierre le Grand 2017  Crozes-Hermitage

Description: There's a reverberating granite undertone to pristine blackberry and plum flavors in this zesty, mineral Syrah. Made from 100% destemmed fruit and aged 12 months in oak (15% new), it offers a purity of cutting black fruit flavors and a long finish marked by firm, gripping tannins. At peak now–2026.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Éric & Jöel Durand 2016 Les Coteaux  (Saint-Joseph)

Appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: The aromas announce themselves with notes of coffee, dark chocolate, huckleberry and spice. Full feeling, high octane blue fruit flavors follow.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Basel Cellars 2018 Co-ferment McKinley Springs Vineyard Syrah (Horse Heaven Hills)

Description: Whiffs of smoked nuts, clove, dried plum and cherry introduce this penetrating, fresh-fruited Syrah. It's medium-bodied and crisply balanced, offsetting juicy, easy-drinking black fruit flavors against brisk acidity and very fine, smooth tannins. Ready to drink now but should hold through 2024.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: M. Chapoutier 2017 Petite Ruche  (Crozes-Hermitage)

Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Description: Cofermented with 6% Viognier, this bold red is velvety smooth, is made from organically grown grapes and is light in ripeness. Blackberry jam, lavender, garrigue and leather make for an Old World, varietally correct and feral experience that works.                      Virginie Boone
Name: Preston 2018 Syrah (Dry Creek Valley)

Description: Wood aging has brought some serious tannins to this ripe wine. It has structure and some still youthful, concentrated fruits. The wine still needs some aging, so drink from late 2021.                      Roger Voss
Name: Quinta de Chocapalha 2016 Mar de Palha Syrah (Lisboa)

Description: From estate-grown fruit, this 100% varietal wine is thick and viscously concentrated in brambly black fruit. The tannins are polished and supple, adding weight and breadth as notes of iron and toasted oak weigh in.                      Virginie Boone
Name: Cuvaison 2018 Diablo Syrah (Los Carneros)

Description: Aged 12 months en barrique, Les Croix is the smokier, spicier Crozes-Hermitage rouge offering from Les Bruyeres. Black plum and blueberry flavors are lusciously ripe, accented by hints of dark chocolate and char, but also a zingy spine of acidity. It's a rounded, ample wine finishing on a touch of dried herbs and fine, smooth tannins. Best now–2027.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Domaine les Bruyeres 2017 Les Croix  (Crozes-Hermitage)

Appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: The aromas announce themselves with notes of coffee, dark chocolate, huckleberry and spice. Full feeling, high octane blue fruit flavors follow.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Basel Cellars 2018 Co-ferment McKinley Springs Vineyard Syrah (Horse Heaven Hills)

Description: Opulent, rich and almost sweet, this superripe, supersmooth wine oozes blackberry jam, maple, black-pepper and dark-chocolate flavors while soft tannins coat the palate.                      Jim Gordon
Name: Klinker Brick 2017 Farráh Syrah (Lodi)

Description: Clairmont is a micro-cooperative of family vignerons, and this crisp, intently mineral Syrah is produced by the Defrance family in honor of their grandmother Élise. Fully destemmed and matured 12 months in French oak, it's a linear red with zippy blackberry and boysenberry flavors etched by hints of smoke, crushed anise and ore. Approachable now but should hold through 2027.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Clairmont 2016 Terre d'Élise  (Saint-Joseph)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: The aromas start out light and elusive, with notes of coffee, mushroom and spice. The flavors start out similarly reserved, fleshing out over time. It has impressive acidity. Best after 2024.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Walla Walla Vintners 2017 Cut Bank Estate Syrah (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: The aromas start out light and elusive, with notes of coffee, mushroom and spice. The flavors start out similarly reserved, fleshing out over time. It has impressive acidity. Best after 2024.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Walla Walla Vintners 2017 Cut Bank Estate Syrah (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Description: Aromas of underbrush, ripe plum, eucalyptus and blue flower lead the way in this Syrah. The straightforward, savory palate offers fleshy black cherry, prune and dark spice alongside polished tannins.                      Kerin O’Keefe
Name: Alessandro di Camporeale 2017 Kaid Syrah (Sicilia)

Appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Description: This full-bodied and well-balanced wine is packed with black figs, dark chocolate and black cherries that flood the palate, supported by moderate tannins.                      Jim Gordon
Name: The Messenger 2018 49 Syrah (Sierra Foothills)

Description: Revitalizing acidity and tart wild raspberry flavor take center stage in this slim, bracingly mineral red. A large proportion of stem inclusion accentuates its vivacious composure and delicate thyme and green pepper tones. Quite quaffable in youth but should hold through 2027.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Vignobles Verzier 2016 Madone  (Saint-Joseph)

Description: Voluptuous and almost ruddy in fruit profile, this is a big-boned, primary red packed with luscious, preserved flavors of blackberry and plum. Open-knit and fleshy on the palate, it's an intensely fruity, pliant Syrah that's best enjoyed now–2024.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Clairmont 2017 Domaine Martinelli L'Idylle  (Crozes-Hermitage)

Appellation: Fair Play, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Description: Not overly ripe or oaky, this firm-textured wine sports tempting woodsmoke, black-pepper and dark-cherry flavors in a texture of moderate tannins and good acidity. It's an appetizing Syrah blended with a dash of Viognier and will be easy to pair with grilled and roasted items.                      Jim Gordon
Name: Omen 2019 Syrah-Viognier (Fair Play)

Description: Blackberry and raspberry notes are restrained on the nose but gain concentration on the palate of this brisk, medium-bodied red. Black fruit flavors are pristine on the palate and elevated by savory hints of smoke, earth and bramble, too. Fine, smooth tannins make it ready to drink now–2024.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Ravoire et Fils 2017 Olivier Ravoire  (Crozes-Hermitage)

Description: Whiffs of black currant candy and violet petals introduce this moderately full-bodied, vibrant Syrah. It's a juicy, approachable red with pristine black cherry and plum flavors that welcome youthful drinking yet firm, gripping tannins lend enough structure for it to hold through 2025.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Brotte 2017 Marandy  (Saint-Joseph)

Description: This is a solid McLaren Vale Shiraz, with a rustic seaside vibe that shows some barnyard reduction at first sniff. It quickly blows off to reveal more appealing aromas like juicy cherry fruit backed by dried herbs, flowers, vanilla and oak. There's a tasty tang to the fruit on the palate. The tannins are on the chewy, drying side but supportive nonetheless.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Chapel Hill 2018 The Parson Shiraz (McLaren Vale)

Description: Black plum and blackberry flavors are primary in this crisply concentrated Syrah. Fresh on its feet and intently granitic, it's an invigorating, peppery red framed by fine-grained, chalky tannins. Best enjoyed now–2023.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Louis Bernard 2017  Crozes-Hermitage

Description: Frey's no-sulfite-added wines are at their best when dark and tannic. This bold, smoky wine needs indulgent food to pair with, and to balance its husky charcoal, black-pepper and grilled herb notes. It's full bodied, very firm in texture and packed with potent grape-skin flavors.                      Jim Gordon
Name: Frey 2019 Biodynamic Syrah (Mendocino)

Appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Description: Clean varietal fruit flavors of wild berries are somewhat hidden by baking-spice, coffee-liqueur, savory herb and skin flavors. It's a potpourri for sure, with a vanilla-tobacco note resonating through the finish.                      Paul Gregutt
Name: Naumes 2017 Syrah (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Description: Scents of vanilla cream and a wide swath of coffee flavor this wine, anchored in brambly blue fruits. It rolls into a tight, stiff, quick finish, with sharp acidity. It was aged 15 months in 30% new oak.                      Paul Gregutt
Name: Griffin Creek 2017 Syrah (Rogue Valley)

Description: Preserved black cherry and boysenberry are intensely ripe, almost ruddy, on the palate of this moderately full-bodied Syrah. Matured in a combination of new and one- to two-year-old oak, it's a rounded, honeyed wine balanced by crisp acidity and dense, mouthdampening tannins. Ready now but should hold through 2027.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Pierre Gaillard 2017 Jeanne Gaillard La Relève  (Saint-Joseph)

Description: Compared with this producer's standard-label Saint-Joseph, six months longer of barrel aging lends piquant accents of cinnamon, clove and tea leaf to rich, ruddy black plum and cassis flavors. Sourced from older vines as well, it's a richer, more concentrated sip framed in very fine, chalky tannins. Ready now but should drink well through 2027.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Domaine du Chêne 2017 Anaïs  (Saint-Joseph)

Description: Produced from 100% destemmed fruit and aged 18 months in oak (50% new), there's a subtle smokiness here reminiscent of hazelnuts and scorched earth that permeates into crisp-tart blackberry and plum flavors. Overall, it's a juicy, fruit-forward Syrah that welcomes youthful drinking, but firm tannins and zesty acidity should hold it through 2025.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Roland Grangier 2017 Côte Granits  (Saint-Joseph)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Raspberry aromas are up front. Soft fruit flavors follow. The heat of the region seems to have carried it away a bit.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Palencia 2018 El Viñador Syrah (Red Mountain)

Description: The shy nose eventually reveals ripe dark-skinned fruit, toasted notes and a whiffs of oak-driven spice. The dense, solid palate offers prune, blackberry extract and hints of baking spice alongside fine-grained tannins.                      Kerin O’Keefe
Name: Planeta 2016 Maroccoli Syrah (Sicilia)

Description: Dried fruit aromas and seemingly sweet flavors give this dark-colored and very full-bodied wine the feel of an after- dinner wine. Rich raisin and prune notes mingle with dark chocolate.                      Jim Gordon
Name: Hyde Vineyard 2017 Estate Syrah (Carneros)

Description: Smooth and savory, this Sicilian Syrah has aromas and flavors of ripe blackberry, raspberry jam, dried mint and ground black pepper. With fresh acidity and polished tannins, it's made to be drunk young so enjoy soon.                      Kerin O’Keefe
Name: Sallier de la Tour 2018 Syrah (Sicilia)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: The aromas of mushroom, herb and black tea aren't fully in harmony. The palate is fleet of foot, bringing an odd mix of overripe and underripe elements.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Spring Valley Vineyard 2017 Estate Grown Nina Lee Syrah (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Description: Concentrated and full bodied, this dark and fully tannic wine offers tight, concentrated black-cherry and cranberry flavors, wrapped in a firm texture. It's a good bet for improving with more age. Best from 2024.                      Jim Gordon
Name: Lava Cap 2017 Estate Bottled Syrah (El Dorado)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Smashed boysenberry, blackberry, leather and cedar resin aromas show on the nose of this bottling. The wine lands broadly on the palate, offering ripe blackberry and tart cranberry flavors, with a penetrating acidity.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Rancho Sisquoc 2018 Syrah (Santa Barbara County)

Description: This has aromas of ripe black-skinned fruit, French oak and grilled herb. The dense, full-bodied palate features blackberry extract, licorice, black pepper and a dollop of vanilla alongside fine-grained tannins.                      Kerin O’Keefe
Designation: M NR L Vigna di Mandranova
Name: Alessandro di Camporeale 2016 M NR L Vigna di Mandranova Syrah (Sicilia)

Description: Plump, juicy black plum and cassis are juxtaposed by savory inflections of smoked nut and earth in this full-bodied Syrah. It's a pleasantly rustic red marked by brisk acidity and fine-grained, lingering tannins. Ready to drink now but should hold through 2024.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Domaine Pradelle 2017  Crozes-Hermitage

Description: Fleshy black plum and cherry flavors dominate this full-bodied, open-knit Syrah. Unoaked and primary in style, it's a ripe, softly textured wine accented by a twist of sour-cherry acidity on the midpalate and fine-grained, easy tannins. At peak now but should maintain through 2024.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Gabriel Meffre 2017 Saint Pierre  (Crozes-Hermitage)

Appellation: Santa Clara Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Pressed cherries and cedar-resin aromas show strongly on the nose of this bottling. Those woody, resiny flavors also consume the palate, which displays hints of dark fruit and pepper spice as well.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Martin Ranch 2017 Therese Vineyards Lester Family Vineyard Syrah (Santa Clara Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Description: This tiny-production wine is layered in baked plum, garrigue and sage. Juicy, soft and sublime on the palate, it delivers rich finishing notes of baked cherry and cola.                      Virginie Boone
Name: Dutton Estate 2017 My Father's Vineyard Syrah (Russian River Valley)

Description: While delicate in concentration, this moderately full-bodied Syrah offers ripe, welcoming flavors of cherry compote and plum preserves layered in dark chocolate and vanilla spice. It's a softly tannic, rounded wine but fresh in acidity. Best now–2025.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Domaine du Chêne 2017  Saint-Joseph

Description: Aromas of sea brine, red berry and dark spice waft out of the glass. On the medium-bodied palate, firm, drying tannins accompany dried cherry and a hint of ground clove.                      Kerin O’Keefe
Name: Tenuta Rapitalà 2017 Nadir Syrah (Sicilia)

Appellation: Moon Mountain District Sonoma County, Sonoma, California, US
Description: Gamy, with strong elements of garrigue and lavender, this wine shows tremendous brawn, smoky oak and velvety lushness on the palate. Veering into overripe fruit, it packs a rich, rounded punch.                      Virginie Boone
Name: Ty Caton 2017 Ballfield Syrah (Moon Mountain District Sonoma County)

Description: Heavily concentrated black-fruit aromas come with graphite and cola notes, while this Navarran single-vineyard Syrah has a grabby, rubbery mouthfeel with notable grapeskin roughness. Salty, lightly herbal black plum and blackberry flavors are oaky and charred, with a distinct aftertaste of black coffee. Rubbery tannins, grainy oak and mild green notes lead a banging finish.                      Michael Schachner
Designation: Xi'ipal La Celada Single Vineyard Baja Montaña San Martín de Unx Limited Edition
Name: Bodegas Caudalía 2015 Xi'ipal La Celada Single Vineyard Baja Montaña San Martín de Unx Limited Edition Syrah (Navarra)

Description: Herbal and earthy, this 100% varietal wine is lively, with dense tannin weight and structure. From a 1,700-foot-elevation site, it has powerful ripeness in the form of brambly blackberry and plum, touches of black licorice and pepper.                      Virginie Boone
Name: Green & Red 2016 Tip Top Vineyard Estate Syrah (Napa Valley)

Description: Aromas of baked plum, violet and cocoa shape the nose. The austere palate is lean in terms of fruit richness, offering prune, clove and ground pepper alongside firm tannins and the warmth of evident alcohol.                      Kerin O’Keefe
Name: Baglio del Cristo di Campobello 2016 Lusirà Syrah (Sicilia)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Aromas of funk, coffee, dark cherry and spice lead to flavors that paint around the edges. The middle seems missing and the overall concentration light.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Bergevin Lane 2016 She-Devil Syrah (Columbia Valley (WA))

Description: Aromas of baked plum, vanilla, mint and cassis follow over to the solid, straightforward palate along with candied notes. Smooth tannins offer light support.                      Kerin O’Keefe
Name: Fondo Antico 2018 Le Clay Syrah (Sicilia)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: The barrel aromas are out front, with notes of baking spice and vanilla. The fruit flavors are light and can't stand up to them. There's nice bright acids but not enough fruit for them to support.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: North by Northwest 2016 Syrah (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Description: Oak scents and flavors dominate this deep, dark, full-bodied wine, giving it sawdust aromas, and woodsmoke and clove on the palate.                      Jim Gordon
Name: Vina Moda 2017 Syrah (Sierra Foothills)

Description: This opens with notes of raspberry, cherry, green peppercorn, briny olives and dried herbs with an amaro-like tinge. There's something a bit soapy and synthetic about the aromas. The palate feels even more forced. It's full bodied but lacking depth of flavor and texture, with oaky tannins and a drying finish that falls off quickly.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Rubus 2018 Shiraz (Barossa)

Appellation: Applegate Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Description: Despite its seriously dark hue, which is almost black at the center, this wine feels all but weightless on the palate. There are drying tannins and not much else. It's a mystery how a wine with that much color and significant listed alcohol can feel so empty.                      Paul Gregutt
Name: Schmidt 2017 Reserve Syrah (Applegate Valley)

Appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Description: This explosively flavorful, age-worthy wine combines complexity, power and finesse in a compelling way. Intricate, spicy aromas of graphite, minerals, black pepper and white pepper lead to a superbly balanced palate of just ripe blackberries, rhubarb and woodsmoke without overdoing any one element. Great balance and layering are its hallmarks. Best from 2026–2040.                      Jim Gordon
Name: Terre Rouge 2017 Ascent Syrah (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Coming from a canyon high up on Red Mountain and aged in 18% new French oak, the aromas pull you into the glass, with notes of mulberry, blackberry, kirsch, earth, crushed rock, coffee and bacon fat. There's depth, intensity, richness, layering, polish, and texture to the palate. The finish is endless. This wine has it all, with the impressive balance, intensity, acidity and length separating it far out front. It sings from the top of Red Mountain. Best after 2026.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Liminal 2018 High Canyon Series WeatherEye Vineyard Syrah (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Fruit for this wine comes from the highest block currently planted on Red Mountain, north facing at the top of the ridge, outside the AVA boundaries. Aged in 25% new French oak, it's the most brooding of the winery's inaugural releases, with notes of dried herb, blackberry, coffee and clove. It's dazzling in its intensity and layering, saturating the palate from end to end while still showing fleetness of foot. Packed full of tannin and acid, it absolutely sails on the finish. The balance is exquisite. Best after 2025.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Designation: Block Highlight Series Block 16 WeatherEye Vineyard
Name: Liminal 2018 Block Highlight Series Block 16 WeatherEye Vineyard Syrah (Columbia Valley (WA))

Description: Packed with pristine black cherry and raspberry flavor, this medium-bodied Syrah is a gloriously perfumed expression of Côte Blonde. It's sunny and charming in fruit profile but elevated by subtle hints of fur, crushed earth and charred bramble, too. While tempting in its youth, it should gain complexity well past 2030.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Domaine Christophe Pichon 2017 La Comtesse en Côte Blonde  (Côte Rôtie)

Appellation: Shenandoah Valley (CA), Sierra Foothills, California, US
Description: Meaty, mineral aromas meet layered and intricate flavors of graphite, violet, dried beef and blackberry in this complex and fascinating wine. It goes well beyond fruit to bring many enticing nuances of salt, pepper and wet rocks to the palate. Best from 2025.                      Jim Gordon
Name: Terre Rouge 2017 Sentinel Oak Vineyard Pyramid Block Syrah (Shenandoah Valley (CA))

Description: This bold, flavorful and nervy wine creates a great tension between its core of raspberry and rhubarb flavors and generous, intriguing accents of mineral, singed herb and grilled beef carried on good acidity and moderate tannins. Best from 2024.                      Jim Gordon
Name: Terre Rouge 2017 DTR Ranch Syrah (Fiddletown)

Appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Perfectly packaged aromas of roasted meats, dark berry fruits, purple flowers and ample baking spice satisfy all one needs in a Syrah. It's plush and generous on the palate, where hearty baked berry flavors are lifted by mace and star anise, cut by light sage and bay leaf and laid atop a soft yet penetrating texture.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Wolff 2018 Syrah (Edna Valley)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Darkly roasted aromas of seared beef, charcoal, blueberry, lavender and purple flowers make for a very intense nose on this bottling. It's lavish on the palate, where dark berries, nutmeg, star anise and cardamom converge atop a creamy yet tense mouthfeel. It offers a great cohesion of spice, fruit, power and finesse.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Peake Ranch 2018 John Sebastiano Vineyard Syrah (Sta. Rita Hills)

Description: A cooling spine of granite lends freshness to pristinely ripe black currant and raspberry flavors here. It's a delicate, finessed Syrah—more ballerina than powerhouse—but penetrating in fruit. Whispers of smoke, licorice and peppery herbs linger on the finish. At peak 2021–2030 but should hold further.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Ferraton Père et Fils 2017 Montmain  (Côte Rôtie)

Description: Radiantly ripe black plum and black cherry notes are muted by hints of earth, leather and ore in this richly tannic, mouthfilling wine sourced from high-altitude sites above the village of Cornas. It's glossy, perfumed style is enticing in its youth but should show even better from 2022 and improve well through 2037.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Ferraton Père et Fils 2017 Les Eygats  (Cornas)

Description: Pure, unadulterated cassis and blackberry extend from nose to finish in this intensely concentrated Syrah. Made from partially destemmed grapes, it's rich and glossy but shaded by hints of dark earth, granite and leather. Ripe, integrated tannins seem coated in cocoa powder and chalk. Approachable already but should improve through 2030 and hold further.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Ferraton Père et Fils 2017 Les Grands Mûriers  (Cornas)

Description: Radiant notes of black raspberry and black-cherry preserves are accentuated by complexities of violet, crushed granite and clove in this pure-fruited, supple wine. Matured for 18 months en barrique (20% new), it's a hedonistic, spicy sip but briskly structured, too, held upright by piercing acidity and firm, gripping tannins. Lovely already but should improve through 2030 and hold further.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Domaine Martin Clerc 2017 Coteau de Tupin  (Côte Rôtie)

Description: Pronounced notes of char and vanilla but also fur and black olive perfume this complex, intriguing Syrah. Blackberry and cherry flavors are sultry on the palate but offset by tart cassis acidity and a bristling granitic finish. At peak 2021–2030 but should hold further.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Ferraton Père et Fils 2017 L'Eglantine  (Côte Rôtie)

Description: Hints of bramble, cacao and anise lend spice to penetrating blackberry and blueberry here. Sourced from high-altitude granite soils, it's a vibrant, freshly composed Syrah. Two years of maturation in oak barrels (50% new) accentuate its rounded mouthfeel and fine-grained, softly tannic finish. Should improve through 2037 and hold further.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Domaine Philippe & Vincent Jaboulet 2016  Cornas

Description: This is an impressive bottling primarily from grapes, including 4% Merlot, grown in the Santa Rosa Valley near the Ventura County city of Camarillo. Dried and bloody beef, black currant and cracked black pepper show on the nose, while the palate offers an intriguing array of charred bacon fat, violet, cassis and more pepper.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Al Lago 2017 Aria Syrah (California)

Description: Whispers of leather saddle, charred earth and smoke penetrate this uniquely rustic Syrah aged 18 months in 30% new barriques. Flavors of black plum and blueberry preserves are intensely concentrated but freshened by a firm, granitic undertone and coarse tannins. Approachable now but should improve through 2030.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Éric & Jöel Durand 2017 Confidence  (Cornas)

Description: Whiffs of violet candy and licorice lend gorgeous perfume to mulberry and cassis here. Made from Syrah sourced from a fully south facing, granite slope, it's decadently ripe but luminous. Rich, ripe tannins envelope a long, penetrating finish. Approachable already but should improve through 2030 and hold further.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Ferraton Père et Fils 2017 Patou  (Cornas)

Description: Whispers of fur, charcuterie and smoke lend savory complexity to luminous cassis and mulberry flavors here. A blend of 97% Syrah and 3% Viognier sourced from schist and mica slopes, it's boasts a gleaming acidic spine and fresh, mineral undertone that are revitalizing. Rich, chewy tannins should meld with time and while appealing already, it's a wine that should peak from 2021–2030 hold further still.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Domaine Christophe Billon 2017 Les Elotins  (Côte Rôtie)

Appellation: Wahluke Slope, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Blackberry and other dark-fruit aromas meld with notes of smoked meat, coffee and mineral. The palate packs a big wallop of rich, layered black-fruit flavors, with plenty of tannic structure to provide support. It's a power-packed, hedonistic delight.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Luke 2018 Reserve Syrah (Wahluke Slope)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Few Central Coast wines age more intriguingly than Santa Lucia Highlands Syrah. This wine is black as night in the glass, and offers aromas of asphalt, black pepper, caramel, fudge and black currant. The palate is dense and wrapped in polished tannins, carrying flavors of black plum, cassis, coffee and light vanilla. Drink now through 2038.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Cattleya 2018 The Initiation Syrah (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Description: Pronounced violet perfume accents blackberry and black currant flavors in this satin-edged Syrah. Matured for 18 months in new and one-year-old French oak, it's a lavish wine streaked by veins of vanilla and smoke but crisp acidity and a flurry of green herbs lend freshness to the mid palate. Firm, gripping tannins need some time to meld but it should be at peak from 2021–2030.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Ravoire et Fils 2017 Olivier Ravoire  (Côte Rôtie)

Description: La Germine is this producer's midrange Côte Rôtie offering relying on older vines than La Chana, and a touch less new oak than the Maison Rouge. It's a gorgeously pure-fruited expression of cassis and black cherries edged by perfumed notes of lilac, dried thyme and anise. Intensely concentrated and silken on the finish, it's lovely young but should improve through 2030 and hold further still.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Domaine Benjamin et David Duclaux 2017 La Germine  (Côte Rôtie)

Description: Sourced from Syrah grown on high-altitude granite slopes, this moderately full-bodied, silken wine offers scintillating black plum and cassis flavors edged by smoke, earth and iron. It's a rich, satisfying wine that's briskly balanced in acidity and framed by fine, penetrating tannins. Lovely already but should gain complexity through 2030.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Domaine Christophe Pichon 2017 Allégorie  (Cornas)

Description: Savory, herbaceous notes of dried violets, bramble and charred underbrush lend elegance to ripe, restrained black cherry and cassis here. This is a slender, sylphlike Syrah with a pert acidic spine and slightly green tannins that lend a peppery bite to the finish. Should reach peak from 2021–2030 but hold longer as well.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Vignobles Verzier 2017 Indiscrète  (Côte Rôtie)

Description: Whispers of violet, licorice and granite extend from nose to finish in this moderately full, succulent red. It's a gloriously ripe, finessed expression of 80-year-old Syrah planted on granitic slopes. Plump and penetrating, it finishes on chalky, mouthfilling tannins. Quite lovely in youth but should improve through 2027.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Alain Voge 2016 Les Vieilles Fontaines  (Cornas)

Description: Sourced from 50-year-old vines planted on schist soils, this is a gloriously concentrated Syrah packed with luminous cassis and blackberry flavors. Prominent oak tones of smoke, vanilla and cacao are balanced by pristine fruit and a bristling acidic edge. It's lovely in its youth but should develop depth and complexity through 2030 and hold further still.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Domaine Christophe Pichon 2017 Rozier  (Côte Rôtie)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Black plum, cardamom and more baking spice aromas kick off the nose of this bottling from a historic vineyard in the newly christened Alisos Canyon appellation (approved after this wine was bottled). Flavors of lavender, lilac and rose petal meet açaí and peppercorns.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Dovecote 2017 Thompson Vineyard Estate Syrah (Santa Barbara County)

Description: Hints of toast, cinnamon and bramble mingle into ripe black raspberry and cassis flavors here. Matured 20 months en barrique (40% new), it's a softly edged, delicately textured sip that falls on smooth, feathery tannins. Approachable in youth but should gain complexity through 2030.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Domaine Benjamin et David Duclaux 2017 Maison Rouge  (Côte Rôtie)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Description: A crisp black-raspberry-sorbet aroma makes for a fresh, inviting interpretation of Syrah by Winemaker Alice Anderson. The palate is grippy in structure, offering tart blackberry and lavender flavors, clinging to that snappy and fresh vibe.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Shokrian Vineyard 2018 Opulent Goat Syrah (Santa Barbara County)

Description: Roasted plum and black cherry compote are accented by whiffs of sweet spice and autumn leaves in this powerfully concentrated Syrah. Moderately full in body, it's opulent but subtly earthen, too, and finishes on ripe, mouthfilling tannins. Approachable already yet should improve through 2027.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: NewRhône Millesimes 2017 Romain Duvernay  (Cornas)

Description: In the style of a Côte-Rôtie blend from the Rhône Valley, the wine is richly textured, mature with plenty of ripe tannins. A mineral texture gives an edge to the wine that makes it both rich and structured. Black-plum fruits and acidity show well at the end. Drink this impressive wine from 2021.                      Roger Voss
Name: Monte da Ravasqueira 2017 Ravasqueira Syrah-Viognier (Alentejano)

Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Description: Wonderful oak complexity gives this full-bodied wine a bounty of clove, cedar and chocolate aromas, leading to a focused core of blackberry and black licorice. It offers major fine-grained tannins and a mouthfilling texture. Best through 2028.                      Jim Gordon
Name: Scott Harvey 2018 J & S Reserve Syrah (Amador County)

Appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Description: This wine exemplifies how complex and enticing Syrah can be when it's not overripe, and lets the sage, char and black-pepper aromas roll. Medium to full bodied, this well-balanced wine is braced by fine-grained tannins surrounding satisfying blackberry and black-currant flavors. Best from 2024.                      Jim Gordon
Name: Terre Rouge 2017 High Slopes Syrah (Sierra Foothills)

Description: A blend of Syrah (and 3% Viognier) sourced from seven different plots of Côte Rôtie, this is a slender, silken sip packed with juicy black raspberry and cherry flavors. It's an immediately approachable, fresh-fruited wine but maintains classic nuances of smoke, bacon fat and crushed earth. The finish is marked by fine, feathery tannins. Best now–2030.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Domaine de Bonserine 2017 La Sarrasine  (Côte Rôtie)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: All of the fruit for this wine comes from Wallula Vineyard in the Horse Heaven Hills. The aromas pop, with notes of freshly chopped parsley, whole tangerine, fresh boysenberry and smoked meat. Rich, layered flavors follow. It brings intensity and depth, but there is still plenty of freshness. But it's the purity and lengthy finish that captivate.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Virtue 2018 Sincerity Syrah (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: San Luis Obispo County, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Crumpled scarlet rose petals, plump violets, açaí sorbet and a light hint of charred meat show on the nose of this bottling. There are ample waves of black pepper on the palate alongside crisp black raspberry, more açaí and graphite flavors, and the fruit grows much richer with air.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Claiborne & Churchill 2018 Spanish Springs Vineyard Syrah (San Luis Obispo County)

Appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Savory aromas of raw lamb and dried charcuterie meet with light lavender, black pepper and carnation on the savory nose of this bottling. The palate carries the cured meat element into an array of other flavors, including crisp yet dark red fruits and rose petals.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Claiborne & Churchill 2018 Syrah (Edna Valley)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Description: This wine is only beginning to gather the elements that will make it a classic for years to come, starting with aromas of savory dried meat, kelp and charred asphalt. The palate's dried purple fruits are lifted by peppercorns, tar and more seashore influence—elements that will all converge in true harmony with time. Drink 2022–2038.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Lucia 2018 Garys' Vineyard Syrah (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: A blend of Wallula (60%) and Stillwater Creek fruit, the aromas are captivating, with notes of dark raspberry, bramble and herb that show a piercing sense of purity. The flavors are dazzling, showing intensity and depth but also elegance and balance. Coffee notes linger on the finish. It's a frankly delicious wine, but it's the structure—and the quality at this price—that impresses most. Best after 2023 with an extremely long life ahead of that.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Structure 2018 Bauhaus Syrah (Columbia Valley (WA))

Description: Like much from this ruggedly dry appellation, this bottling is tightly wound and should stand the test of time. Dark aromas of black currant, crisp blackberry, violet, game and graphite lead into a tense, chalky palate with dark fruit and black pepper flavors. Drink 2022–2037.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Indigené 2017 Parenthesis Syrah (Chalone)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: The aromas offer notes of iron, firepit, stem, Mandarin orange and black olive—classically Rocks District. The firepit and other savory flavors are intense, bringing textural richness, lingering on the finish. It's the winery's most complete and captivating offering from the Rocks to date.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Betz Family 2018 Domaine de Pierres Syrah (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Ballard Canyon, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Pure and lively aromas of purple flowers, wet rocks and damp soil show on the nose of this bottling, which will benefit from a bit of patience. Brisk flavors of raspberry, cola, chalk and lavender show much promise on the palate, which is tightly wrapped in staff tannins at this young age. Drink 2022–2034.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Stolpman 2019 Estate Syrah (Ballard Canyon)

Description: Intriguing whiffs of fur, charred earth and violet perfume this freshly concentrated Syrah made from destemmed grapes and vinified with native yeast. It's a refreshingly classic, spry expression of Côte Rôtie compared with increasingly richer, riper ones. The long finish is marked by velvet, persistent tannins. Lovely already but should improve through 2027.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Domaine B. Burgaud 2017  Côte Rôtie

Description: Intensely ripe, luscious cassis and mulberry flavors maintain the same perfumed, spicy tone of this producer's Coteau de Tupin bottling, but there's a breathtaking freshness here accentuated by a pleasantly green, herbaceous tone. It's a moderately full-bodied, freshly concentrated sip that finishes on fine, feathery tannins. Ready now but should hold through 2030.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Domaine Martin Clerc 2017 Collet  (Côte Rôtie)

Appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Description: This brand is deeply exploring the whole-cluster and carbonic treatments to present fresh, lively and quaffable wines. Aromas of black raspberry bubblegum, smoked sage and thyme kick off the nose, while a mix of savory and fruity tones consume the palate, from red plum and roasted strawberry to peppercorns, herbs and a leather-kissed finish.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Folded Hills 2019 Cluster Nouveau Syrah (Santa Ynez Valley)

Appellation: Marin County, North Coast, California, US
Description: Crystalline aromas of boysenberry meet with singed sagebrush, white pepper and crushed rocks on the nose of this bottling by Bryan Harrington, one of his final wines before retiring his brand. Tart black-plum skin and spicy white pepper ride taut tannins on the sip, with a singed beef-loin flavor emerging toward the finish.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Harrington 2018 McEvoy Ranch Syrah (Marin County)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: The heart of this wine is fruit from the original 1986 plantings at this vineyard, the first Syrah vines in the state. The aromas pop, with notes of mulberry, huckleberry, dark plum, leather, fresh clove, spice and dark fruit. Full fruit flavors follow, bringing tannic heft that augurs well for its longevity. Best after 2025.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Designation: La Côte Patriarche Red Willow Vineyard
Name: Betz Family 2018 La Côte Patriarche Red Willow Vineyard Syrah (Yakima Valley)

Description: Maturation in new French oak lends prominent accents of char, vanilla and nutmeg to this glossy, black fruited Syrah. It's a flamboyant, intensely luscious sip packed with crème de cassis and mulberry flavors, but precisely composed, too. Youthful fruit flavors are immediately hedonistic, but the coarse, gripping tannins should meld better through 2030.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Cave de Tain 2017 Arènes Sauvages  (Cornas)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Cofermented with 6% Viognier, the aromas are lifted, with notes of boysenberry pie, fresh flower and orange peel. It's a mouthful of blue- and purple-fruit flavors, showing impressive freshness and deftness for this warm appellation.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Betz Family 2018 La Côte Rousse Syrah (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: This blend of Stillwater Creek, Wallula and Red Willow fruit is everything there is to love about this variety: compelling aromatics and great depth of flavor. Alluring aromas of flower fresh, chopped parsley, boysenberry, smoked meat and medicine lead to full-bodied layered flavors. Though delicious now, it appears it will be near eternal.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Structure 2018 Foundation Syrah (Columbia Valley (WA))

Description: Ripe, luminous plum preserve and cassis liqueur abound in this supple oak-aged Syrah. Sourced from younger vines (15–30 years old), it's a fresher, more primary expression of Cornas than the producer's Confidence or Empreintes bottlings. It's ready to enjoy in its youth but should hold through 2027.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Éric & Jöel Durand 2017 Prémices  (Cornas)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Dense aromas of baked blackberry, purple flowers, loamy soil, light smoke and cocoa dust show on the nose of this bottling. The palate is firm and concentrated, offering cassis and violet flavors supported by strong acidity and a tight tannic structure.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Indigené 2017 Parenthesis Syrah (Sta. Rita Hills)

Description: Sourced from young Syrah vines (15–20 years old) planted on a bedrock of gneiss, this is a fresh, pertly composed red. Black currant and cassis flavors are pure and pristine, edged by whispers of anise and black pepper and fine, feathery tannins. A youthful, vibrant style of Côte Rôtie to enjoy now–2030.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Domaine Benjamin et David Duclaux 2017 La Chana  (Côte Rôtie)

Description: This is a bit closed upon opening, suggesting more earth and smoke than fruit, but some time and aeration coax out ripe, rich notes of black cherry and plum compote. It's a soft, fleshy Cornas accented by hints of smoked nut and leather anise and coated in soft, yielding tannins. Approachable now but should hold through 2027.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Domaine des Remizières 2017  Cornas

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Blackberry, smoked meat, plum, dried herb and medicine aromas lead to expressive fruit flavors, with light Robitussin cough-syrup accents. It puts a premium on elegance. The most backward initially of the 2018 releases, it is tightly clenched at present. Best after 2025.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Betz Family 2018 La Serenne Boushey Vineyard Syrah (Yakima Valley)

Description: Enticing notes of rose petal, charred earth and underbrush accent intensely ripe, glossy cassis in this slim, spry Côte Rôtie. It's intensely ripe but freshly balanced and finishes on pert, upright tannins. Ready to approach now but should hold through 2027.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Louis Bernard 2017  Côte Rôtie

Appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Although nearly five years old already, this bottle is still firm and tight. Aromas of crisp elderberry, lavender, white pepper and asphalt lead into a palate of black pepper, violet and iodine flavors, proving intense and still rigid. Drink through 2031.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Zaca Mesa 2016 Mesa Reserve Estate Vineyard Syrah (Santa Ynez Valley)

Description: A balanced blend of Côte Brune's power and Côte Blonde's sunny charm, this medium-bodied but luscious Syrah calibrates smoky, slightly meaty complexities against pristine blackberry and raspberry flavor. It's a juicy, immediately enjoyable wine accentuated by soft, feathery tannins and a lingering whisper of ore. At peak through 2030.                      Anna Lee C. Iijima
Name: Gabriel Meffre 2017 Laurus  (Côte Rôtie)

Appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
Description: It's hard to find better value than what McPrice Myers is doing with his “Hard Working Wines.” This bottling offers roasted coffee, toasted wood and blistered black plum on the savory, engaging and comforting nose. The palate is also toasty, and focused on grilled blackberry flavors.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: McPrice Myers 2018 Right Hand Man Syrah (Central Coast)

Appellation: Wahluke Slope, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Aromas of black raspberry, scorched earth and pomegranate lead to rich fruit flavors. It's a no holds barred, rich, intense Syrah. Decant if drinking in the near term.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Luke 2018 Syrah (Wahluke Slope)

Appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Seared game, pressed blackberry, roasted meat and a slight hint of sage show on the nose of this bottling. The roasted meat aspect continues on the palate, where black pepper, violet and a brush of iodine also play with the grilled boysenberry flavors.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Folded Hills 2018 Adolphus Syrah (Santa Ynez Valley)

Appellation: Santa Clara Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Iodine, boysenberry, smoked beef, violet and soy show on the dynamic nose of this single-vineyard expression. The palate is more dense and ripe, offering black currant, baked berry pie, hint of lilac and cedar and firm tannins.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Martin Ranch 2017 Therese Vineyards Dos Ninos Vineyard Syrah (Santa Clara Valley)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: This wine could only come from one place, with its aromas of wet rock, savory herb, flower, plum, orange rind and olive brine. The palate shows a sense of deftness to the fruit and savory flavors, along with the Rocks District's plush feel.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Proper 2018 Estate Syrah (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Dense, thick and somewhat smoky aromas of dark-purple fruits make for a hefty nose on this bottling from the oldest block of Syrah in Santa Barbara County, planted in 1978. Firm tannins and strong acidity frame the palate, where those dark fruits meet with savory cured meat flavors.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Zaca Mesa 2016 Black Bear Block Syrah (Santa Ynez Valley)

Appellation: Ballard Canyon, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Stewed black-plum and prune aromas show on the very rich and ripe nose of this bottling. The palate is more balanced and judicious, combining the plum and fig flavors with pepper, baking spice and coffee cream.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Kaena 2017 Tierra Alta Vineyard Syrah (Ballard Canyon)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Ciel du Cheval fruit makes up 71% of this wine, with the rest from StoneTree. Aromas of coffee, lavender, earth and assorted dried herbs are followed by a sleek but flavorful palate that shows the acidity of the vintage. Drink now.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: DeLille 2017 Signature Syrah (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: This wine comes from one of the state's top Syrah sites. Compelling aromas of dark raspberry, bramble, smoked meat and medicine lead to plentiful, lightly tacky-feeling fruit flavors. The acid of the vintage drives it, and it shows an impeccable sense of balance. Drink in the near-ish term.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Structure 2017 Red Willow Vineyard Syrah (Yakima Valley)

Description: This luscious, generous wine manages to harness the perfumes and structure of the grape with great style. It is a rich wine, powerful and dense while also having elegance and freshness. Drink now.                      Roger Voss
Name: Quinta da Lapa 2017 Reserva Syrah (Tejo)

Appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Focused aromas of boysenberry, light violet and lavender show on the nose of this bottling. The palate snaps with boysenberry, black-plum and tart elderberry flavors, with a hint of those purple flowers, set atop very strong acidity.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Agharta 2017 Syrah (Central Coast)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: The aromas offer notes of orange oil, smoked meat, medicine, fresh herb and dark fruit. An assortment of sleek-feeling orange-peel, plum and savory flavors follow, with the orange notes showing prominently at present. Coffee flavors linger on the finish.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Airfield Estates 2017 Reserve Syrah (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: The aromas suggest notes of iron, medicine and earth, along with dark berry. The palate has depth of flavor but with an acidic snap that ups the ante.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: DeLille 2016 Grand Ciel Syrah (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Though founder Bob Lindquist is no longer part of this winery, the brand still delivers value-driven Syrah. Aromas of roasted meat, black pepper, lavender and light berries kick off the nose, while the savory palate blends pepper, crisp fruit and dried herb flavors into an easy-to-quaff, light-bodied expression.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Qupé 2018 Syrah (Central Coast)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Coming from one of the state's top Syrah sites, aromas of spice, dark fruit and sugared plum lead to raspberry flavors that are more restrained than the aromas might suggest. It shows the riper side of the variety.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Gorman 2018 Sleeping Giant Boushey Vineyard Syrah (Yakima Valley)

Description: Delicious and mouthfilling, this full-bodied wine is drenched in jammy blackberry and blueberry flavors on a rather soft and easy texture. The saturated fruitiness stays on the palate through a lingering finish.                      Jim Gordon
Name: Michael David 2018 Sixth Sense Syrah (Lodi)

Appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Description: Ripe, jammy but not quite sweet, this full-bodied wine overflows with blackberry and huckleberry-pie flavors that are rich and layered. It's easy to swallow and not very tannic.                      Jim Gordon
Name: Vina Moda 2018 Syrah (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Aromas of barnyard, hay and berry lead to fruit and savory flavors that are more sleek and center focused than the norm for this producer. As with many wines from this vintage, there is a pleasing acidic snap.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Gorman 2017 The Pixie Syrah (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Description: The college students continue to impress on these bottlings. This bottling begins with thyme, lavender, white pepper and açaí aromas on the nose. The palate picks up dust and leather, giving earthy depth to the boysenberry and black-plum flavors.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Allan Hancock 2018 Syrah (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Temecula Valley, South Coast, California, US
Description: Muddled plums, blackberry, wet stone and a hint of teriyaki show on the nose of this bottling. Firm tannins uphold flavors of purple flower and black plum, leading into a savory midpalate of soy and Worcestershire sauces and finishing with a vanilla kick.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Europa Village 2017 C'est la Vie Wine Chateau Syrah (Temecula Valley)

Appellation: Wahluke Slope, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: The aromas bring notes of manure, licorice, berry and whiffs of oak spice. Especially considering the warmth of the vintage, the palate is surprisingly reserved, trailing on the finish.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Lobo Hills 2015 StoneTree Vineyard Syrah (Wahluke Slope)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Showing some reduction initially, the aromas suggest notes of char, black raspberry and gravel. The palate is deft and up front, trailing a bit toward the finish but overall showing good balance. There's plenty of value to be had.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Lone Birch 2018 Estate Grown Syrah (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Blistered black plum and boysenberry meet with a slight wet wool aroma on the nose of this bottling. The palate offers slightly sour black fruits and tart berries with a strong acidic backbone.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Midnight 2017 Nocturne Syrah (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Description: Menthol and dill aromas lead to rich black-fruit flavors in this spicy, oak-accented and full-bodied wine. It's broad in mouthfeel and leaves a lingering spicy finish.                      Jim Gordon
Name: Scott Harvey 2018 Mountain Selection Syrah (Amador County)

Appellation: San Luis Obispo County, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Very ripe and rich aromas of blackberry syrup and grape seed show on the lush nose of this bottling from a unique vineyard north of the Santa Maria Valley. Gooey flavors of black-plum pudding and black-currant paste lead into a caramel-soaked finish.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Kaena 2016 Alamo Creek Ranch Syrah (San Luis Obispo County)

Description: A reduced, earthy aroma at first sniff blows off in a few minutes and leads to tasty plum, woodsmoke and chocolate flavors in this sturdy, full-bodied wine.                      Jim Gordon
Name: Terre Rouge 2017 Les Côtes De L'Ouest Syrah (California)

Description: A soft, lightly wood aged wine, this is ripe, easygoing and full of young, vibrant fruit. Acidity, fruitiness and light tannins hang together well. Drink now.                      Roger Voss
Name: Monte da Ravasqueira 2019 Syrah (Alentejano)

Appellation: Ramona Valley, South Coast, California, US
Description: Smoked beef-bone, extracted lavender and candied grape-sorbet aromas arise on the nose of this bottling. There are roasted fennel, smoked berry and baked fruit flavors on the palate.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Castelli Family Vineyards 2015 Syrah (Ramona Valley)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Bold amounts of green peppercorn, sansho pepper, mixed olives and iodine meet with a tense black-raspberry aroma on this cool-climate Syrah. The palate is wild and amazingly herbal in flavor, with tea leaf, nettle and bay leaf elements and just enough lingering dark-berry fruit to fill it out.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Holus Bolus 2018 Franc de Pied Syrah (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Description: An extreme version of cool-climate Syrah, this bottling begins with peppercorn, bay leaf, asphalt, green olive and eucalyptus on the nose as well as a pleasant black-raspberry-fruit element. It's very lively on the palate, where the green-peppercorn and Kalamata olive flavors meet with gamy meats and tart black plum.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Holus Bolus 2018 Presqu'ile Vineyard Syrah (Santa Maria Valley)

Description: Winemaker David Ramey sources from both Cole Creek and Rodgers Creek vineyards to make this wine, cofermenting it with 11% Viognier. Crushed rock, garrigue, gamy meat and lavender appear and accent an earthy, full-bodied core of silky texture and luscious dark cherry.                      Virginie Boone
Name: Ramey 2017 Syrah (Sonoma Coast)

Description: A deep well of aromas fill this wine: plum, cherry, cocoa nibs, rose, violets, earthy herbs, baked clay and a charred note, like the pan scrapings of a roast. The palate is velvety and downright sexy, with spicy tannins and terracotta components adding complexity and austerity to the plush, almost playful fruit. It shows a power play of muscle and elegance. Drink now with a slab of charred red meat or age through 2030.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Giant Steps 2018 Syrah (Yarra Valley)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Description: The Santa Lucia Highlands is one of the best places to grow Syrah in California, despite being overshadowed by Pinot Noir. This bottling is thorough evidence, with suavely integrated aromas of black pepper, black currant, lavender and crushed black stones. Firm, sticky tannins frame the palate, where pepper, green olive and bay leaf flavors decorate the inky black-fruit core. Drink 2023–2043.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Mansfield-Dunne 2018 Cortada Alta Vineyard Syrah (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Los Olivos District, Central Coast, California, US
Description: There's a spicy core of black pepper on the nose of this bottling along with taut fruit tones of wid cranberry and elderberry. The palate is loaded with acid and tightly woven in texture, delivering flavors of crumpled lavender, crisp black raspberry, Dr Pepper spice and an incredibly enlivening cracked pepper streak.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Margerum 2018 Margerum Estate Vineyard Syrah (Los Olivos District)

Description: Thanks in part to the relatively cool year, this is a wine that manages refinement, restraint and beautiful expression of place. The nose is a neatly woven basket of aromas: crushed flowers, red and blue fruit, pepper, mint and cigar box. The palate is full figured and highly textural. There's a line of powdery, spicy, ultrafine tannins and a streak of high-end oak. Set up for a long life, drink from 2022–2045 at least.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Hickinbotham 2017 Brooks Road Shiraz (McLaren Vale)

Appellation: Los Olivos District, Central Coast, California, US
Description: There's a spicy core of black pepper on the nose of this bottling along with taut fruit tones of wid cranberry and elderberry. The palate is loaded with acid and tightly woven in texture, delivering flavors of crumpled lavender, crisp black raspberry, Dr Pepper spice and an incredibly enlivening cracked pepper streak.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Margerum 2018 Margerum Estate Vineyard Syrah (Los Olivos District)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Description: The Santa Lucia Highlands is one of the best places to grow Syrah in California, despite being overshadowed by Pinot Noir. This bottling is thorough evidence, with suavely integrated aromas of black pepper, black currant, lavender and crushed black stones. Firm, sticky tannins frame the palate, where pepper, green olive and bay leaf flavors decorate the inky black-fruit core. Drink 2023–2043.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Mansfield-Dunne 2018 Cortada Alta Vineyard Syrah (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Very dark in the glass, this single-vineyard bottling from a unique vineyard high in the rocky mountains above the Santa Maria Valley shows incredible intensity on the nose, with dark berry, plum, cocoa, cola and light floral freshness. The palate is purely purple and black fruits, enhanced by crushed espresso bean and cracked pepper—a head-turner wine.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Tensley 2018 Colson Canyon Vineyard Syrah (Santa Barbara County)

Description: German-born winemaker Timo Mayer is one of Australia's small batch, natural wine rock stars. Known for his deft use of 100% whole bunch, Mayer's Syrah is a vibrant and characterful tipple. The color of cherry juice, it's intensely spicy and medicinal, like an Italian amaro, bouncing with tangy rhubarb, red currant and orange peel flavors. The palate takes a more classical turn, the amaro flavors takes a back seat to raspy tannins and wonderfully spiky acidity. This is an idiosyncratic wine from an idiosyncratic producer that's ultradrinkable and would pair well with piles of smoked meat or grilled portobellos.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Mayer 2018 Syrah (Yarra Valley)

Description: With 2% Viognier, this red is lifted in bright aromatics and underlying crispness—a cool-climate style that's both fresh and complex. Black and white pepper, feral earth, raspberry, plum and garrigue all make their way to the palate, mingling and contrasting well before a graceful, delicate finish.                      Virginie Boone
Name: Anthill 2017 Peters Vineyard Syrah (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Description: This county-wide blend is made in a powerful style, offering rich aromas of black currant, blackberry, bacon and maple sugar. The palate is quite satisfying in that a lush way, showing blueberry and violet flavors in a strong yet accessible and balance manner.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Margerum 2018 Syrah (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Crumpled purple flowers give a floral kick to the nose of this bottling, which is also full of dark blackberry at its core and pinches of pepper on the edges. Herbal tones of crushed thyme, peppercorn and bay leaf arise on the sip, giving nuance to the dark-berry core, with popping acidity driving into the finish.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Tensley 2018 Syrah (Sta. Rita Hills)

Description: The cool vintage has done great things for Torbreck's most premium Shiraz. While it still sports broad shoulders, this bottling offers dashes of elegance and freshness. Black currant, plum, beet root, cocoa powder and gentle herbs and spices are supported by cola-like oak. The tannins are muscular but fine, tautly woven into the sleek mouthfeel. This should be a stunner with time. Drink 2022–2040.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Torbreck 2017 RunRig Shiraz-Viognier (Barossa Valley)

Appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Backed blackberry, bloody meats, smoke and a hint of caramel show on the nose of this richer style of Syrah from this winery. The tannins are smooth and polished on the sip, where rounded flavors of roasted blackberry, mesquite and iodine converge.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Dragonette 2016 MJM Syrah (Santa Ynez Valley)

Appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Gamy qualities of pepper-crusted lamb shanks meet with a muddled mulberry and cherry backdrop on the nose of this bottling. The palate is taut and grippy in texture, loaded with pepper, roasted lamb and a pinch of rosemary, yet it all plays against a fresh fruit backdrop and proves relatively lighter in body.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Dragonette 2017 Seven Syrah (Santa Ynez Valley)

Description: This lovely, balanced and complex red wine—100% varietal—is cool-climate in style and approach. Earth and leather meet a core of fresh juicy plum that is lifted and brightened in fresh acidity, with appropriate notes of garrigue, lavender and white pepper.                      Virginie Boone
Name: Anthill 2017 Campbell Ranch Syrah (Sonoma Coast)

Description: Dark tones of smashed black raspberry are dusted with thyme, green peppercorns and wood ash on the dynamic nose of this bottling from just south of Santa Rosa. The palate is tightly wound in texture yet rich in flavors of blackberry, boysenberry and lavender, all cut by savory hits of cracked pepper and tobacco leaf.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Sandler 2018 Nolan Vineyard Syrah (Bennett Valley)

Appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Description: Seriously delicious, this well-structured and full-bodied wine packs in tons of blackberry and black-cherry fruit along with hints of wood smoke, black pepper and crushed stones. It is moderately tannic and seems well built for aging. Best through 2028.                      Jim Gordon
Name: Holly's Hill 2018 Fenaughty Old Vines Syrah (El Dorado)

Description: It's easy to overlook this wine in a sea of ripe, flashy South Aussie Shiraz. But give this broody, cool climate wine your time as well as time in decanter and its singularity and precision shine. Notes of brambly berries and orange rind are accompanied by savory, earthy spices, dark chocolate and something sanguine and mineral-driven. The palate is big and a tad austere, with powerful, taut, chalky tannins, lifted acidity and layers of fruit and spice. Showing more elegance than past vintages of this wine. Drink 2021–2035.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Jasper Hill 2017 Georgia's Paddock Shiraz (Heathcote)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Aromas of tar, charred blueberries, rose petals and black-raspberry sorbet make for a very fresh entry to the nose of this bottling. Fruity flavors of black currant and blueberry are fresh on the palate, followed by spicier hints of white pepper.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Margerum 2018 Black Oak Vineyard Syrah (Santa Barbara County)

Description: This wine offers meaty, leathery and earthy tones. Cloves, bay leaf and baked clay mingle with plump plum and cherry fruit. Oak is present but in the background. The textural tannins are granular and savory, rounded out by plush fruit. Again, the oak shows its face, as does the alcohol, but the combo of complexity and approachability this wine achieves forgives both these things. Drink now–2035.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Torbreck 2017 Descendant Shiraz-Viognier (Barossa Valley)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Though this wine starts a little shy on the nose, it slowly reveals elegant blackberry and violet aromas with time. The palate takes those purple-fruit and flower flavors and amplifies the experience with espresso-bean touches.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Margerum 2018 Uber Syrah (Santa Barbara County)

Description: The nose of this wine is initially rich and comforting in tones of chocolate and Christmas spices amidst red berry fruit. With time, the fruit gets brighter and more nuanced floral and savory characters emerge. The palate is powerful but poised, with textural tannins and juicy fruit. Drink until 2030 at least.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Angove 2018 Warboys Vineyard Shiraz (McLaren Vale)

Description: From a cooler year, this wine wears the vintage conditions most transparently. Waves of aromas wash to shore: plum, currant, licorice, mocha, warm stones and baking spices. The oak and alcohol aren't completely invisible, but vineyard character and fruit purity take center stage. Juicy berries, warm spices and firm, powdery tannins abound. Drink now–2040.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Torbreck 2017 The Factor Shiraz (Barossa Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: This is a new addition to the lineup, from an area—the Royal Slope—that is coming to be known for its Syrah. The aromas are bright, with notes of tangerine zest, flower, cigar leaf, medicine and red and blue plum. It's loaded with blue fruit flavors. A light eucalyptus note lingers on the long finish. It's fascinating and impressive stuff.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Latta 2017 Lawrence Vineyards Syrah (Columbia Valley (WA))

Description: From the cool, maritime climes of Great Southern in Western Australia, this Syrah is miles away from the sun-soaked South Aussie Shiraz stereotype. There's a bounce of stalky spice on the nose that mingles with brambly red berries, black olives and stony minerals. Underneath is a pleasing funk. Light to medium bodied, the spicy palate is held together by sinewy, savory tannins. Drink with roast lamb or grilled mushrooms.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Snake and Herring 2015 Redemption Syrah (Great Southern)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Baked and blistered plum aromas meet with roasted meats, lilac and lavender on the nose of this appellation blend. The flavors begin with smoked meats and dark berry on the palate, where underlying herb tones of bay leaf, juniper and thyme are lifted by cracked pepper.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Holus Bolus 2018 Syrah (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Dark fruit aromas are wrapped up in crushed stone, charred wood and dry soil elements on the nose of this bottling. The palate is very floral, offering flavors of crumpled lavender and violet, with hints of tar and inky fruit as a taut structure packs it all together.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Bien Nacido Estate 2018 Syrah (Santa Maria Valley)

Description: With 4% Viognier, the nose of this Shiraz-based wine offers an appealing mix of plum, fig cake, mocha, olive and large helpings of savory spice. The palate is powerfully tannic and chalky in texture. Nevertheless, the spicy, brambly fruit finds its way to the fore, providing much needed softness. Give this a decant or air time or plenty of protein if drinking now. Drink until 2028.                      Christina Pickard
Name: D'Arenberg 2016 The Laughing Magpie Shiraz-Viognier (McLaren Vale)

Appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Description: This full-bodied and powerfully fruity wine drenches the palate with ripe blackberries and blueberries carried on a rich texture. With all that fruit and light baking spices from oak, the underlying tannins seem soft and easy.                      Jim Gordon
Name: E16 2018 Baby Rattlesnake Vineyard Syrah (El Dorado)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Description: Boom! The aromas explode from the glass, with notes of fresh flowers, whole and squeezed Satsuma orange, blueberry pie, black pepper, plum, smoked meat and earth, showing a captivating sense of purity and clarity. It's pillowy soft, full of fruit, olive and smoked meat flavors that undulate across the palate. The smoked meat and orange twist finish is a full 30-plus seconds. Dee-licious.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Rôtie Cellars 2018 Northern Blend Rocks Estate Syrah (Walla Walla Valley (OR))

Description: This is a sturdy example of McLaren Vale Shiraz that offers with a deep well of flavor in the form of cherry, blackberry, spice, olivs, savory underbrush and flecks of dark chocolate. The oak is present but supportive. In the mouth, plush fruit is layered with firm, granular tannins, lifted acidity, and barrel influence. It's a bit rustic, with a savory, iodine-like finish. Drink now–2028.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Maxwell 2016 Ellen Street Shiraz (McLaren Vale)

Description: A juice bomb in the best sense, this wine bursts from the glass with aromas of fresh squeezed cherry juice and watermelon Jolly Rancher. There are some stalky, peppery, floral and licorice notes lingering at the back, too. The palate is an acid-lover's dream. While it may be overly puckering for some, like biting into a lemon, the freshness is welcome, particularly balanced with spicy, textured tannins. It's a fun-loving barbecue wine for drinking slightly chilled.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Living Roots 2018 Pepperberry Shiraz (Adelaide Hills)

Description: This is a cofermented blend of 95% Syrah with 5% Viognier from a warm site and a warm vintage. Meaty, it tastes of blueberry jam, iron and garrigue, all velvety smooth and compelling. Lavender, herb and black pepper adorn the fruit and add contrast and intrigue.                      Virginie Boone
Name: Gondak Cellars 2017 Collective Efforts Lawer Vineyard Syrah-Viognier (Knights Valley)

Appellation: Yorkville Highlands, North Coast, California, US
Description: An attractive, savory, roasted herb element sets this wine apart from the pack, giving it tasty complexity to complement a core of blackberry and light black-pepper flavors. Not a monster wine, but a poised and distinctive one.                      Jim Gordon
Name: Meyer Family Cellars 2016 High Ground Syrah (Yorkville Highlands)

Description: This is the label of Emily McNally, who's family owns the renowned Jasper Hill winery. Grown in granite soils, this is a hearty yet harmonious Victoria Shiraz. A tang of red fruit and plums is underlaid with soft tones of flowers, mocha, bay leaf and Christmas spices. Muscular yet fine-grained, textural tannins are juxtaposed with a lift of acidity. Oak is neatly tucked away. One has to do a double take to realize the 15.5% alcohol, since it's far from obvious. Drink 2021–2035.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Occam's Razor 2017 Shiraz (Heathcote)

Description: This organic, biodynamic wine succeeds in delivering a harmonious and approachable expression of Shiraz that evokes a forrest floor surrounded by wild berry bushes. The plump fruit and woodsy spice—along with mocha, olive and violet characters—flow to the palate. The fruit is silky, yet neatly wound in granular tannins. The lengthy finish is savory and spicy. Drink now–2028.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Paxton 2018 Quandong Farm Shiraz (McLaren Vale)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Coming from this esteemed site in Yakima Valley, aromas of stem, moist earth, smoked meat and black pepper are followed by tart, lip-smacking flavors that ramp up in intensity with time open. Grainy tannins back it up. It needs time to show its best. Drink after 2025. Pair it with grilled meat.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Gramercy 2017 Lagniappe Red Willow Vineyard Syrah (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: The aromas are subdued for the Rocks District but still draw you into the glass, with notes of olive, freshly mortared herb, plum, orange twist, firepit and moist earth. The flavors are layered, showing depth and intensity.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Latta 2017 Dana Dibble Freewater Rocks Vineyard Syrah (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Description: The distinctive, rustic style of this historic winery is on display in this premium Shiraz made from the oldest block on the property. A nose of forest berries, cumin, mocha and baking spices leads to a powerful, textured palate. With more freshness than in previous vintages, this allows some fruit character to shine, although the tannins are still massive and the oak a tad prominent. This needs time and plenty of it, but should be a lovely one for the cellar. Drink 2023–2030.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Kay Brothers 2017 Amery Vineyard Block 6 Handpicked Shiraz (McLaren Vale)

Appellation: Oak Knoll District, Napa, California, US
Description: Earthy with floral aromas of rose petal, this is a delicate, dry and savory wine, reflective of its variety. Citrus notes meat an underbelly of meat, garrigue and dried herb, finishing in an interesting flair of lemongrass.                      Virginie Boone
Name: Eleven Eleven 2019 Destin Vineyard Rosé of Syrah (Oak Knoll District)

Description: This wine is from a selection of fruit from across the Barossa and so has less site character than some of the single-vineyard wines, but that distinctive Torbreck signature of plush fruit, polished oak, plenty of alcohol and oodles of charm. Fistfuls of dried mint, oregano, bay leaf and crushed violets partner with blackberry, blueberry, baked clay and the toasty, chocolatey notes of high end barrels. On the tongue, it's rich and satiny, with a touch of alcohol heat and oak influence but it still shows lovely fruit that's all soft corners. Drink now–2028.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Torbreck 2018 The Struie Shiraz (Barossa)
