Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: There's plenty of aromas of smoked meat, fresh herb, white pepper, violet and raspberry. The flavors are light but layered. It's mouthwatering and juicy, a terrific value that will shine at the dinner table.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Gramercy 2017 Lower East Syrah (Columbia Valley (WA))

Description: The relatively cool hand of the 2017 vintage has added touches of freshness and elegance to many classically rich, powerful wines like this one. Postcard McLaren Vale notes of plums, blackberries, peppery, earthy spices and a little well-placed oak lead the way. The distinction is in the palate, where muscular, highly textural, rustic tannins are balanced by bright, juicy fruit. Not for fans of cushy, soft-around-the-middle Shiraz, but tannin-craving red lovers will find much enjoyment.                      Christina Pickard
Name: D'Arenberg 2017 The Dead Arm Shiraz (McLaren Vale)

Appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Dense blackberry, cured meats and wood-smoke aromas show on the nose of this bottling from the Donati Vineyard. The palate balances tannic tension with fresh acidity, offering flavors of smoked coffee-crusted beef loin in a blackberry compote.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Timbre 2017 The Hook Syrah (Edna Valley)

Description: The nose of this medium-bodied Shiraz is a heady combo of baking spice, plum, brambly berry fruit and licorice. Powdery tannins are supportive while leaving room for the tangy, juicy fruit. That lovely spice pops back up on the finish. Plonk on the dinner table beside a meat or veggie roast.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Bremerton 2017 Selkirk Shiraz (Langhorne Creek)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Tart black-plum aromas meet with tangy violets and a bit of tar on the nose of this bottling. Roasted berry, coffee and bacon flavors show on the palate, where tart plum-skin flavors come through onto the finish.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Falcone 2018 Syrah (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Wet stone, pink-rose-petal and strawberry aromas show on the nose of this bottling from a new project by Sante Arcangeli owner John Benedetti. The sip zips with acidity, delivering watermelon and lime flavors across a texturally engaging palate.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Origin 2019 Lester Family Vineyard Rosé of Syrah (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Sixty-one percent of the fruit for this wine comes from Boushey Vineyard—and it shows—with the rest from Olsen. Aromas of funk, earth, iron, coffee and barrel spice are followed by dense, rich, hedonistic blue flavors. It brings a compelling savory element.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Sparkman 2017 Darkness Syrah (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Description: An emerging strength in the Rogue, this nicely bookends the sensational Syrahs from the northeast corner of the state in the Rocks District AVA. Briary berry and plum fruit is swathed in lush barrel flavors (25% new) of creamy mocha. The tannins retain some herbaceous bite.                      Paul Gregutt
Name: Valcan 2015 Syrah (Rogue Valley)

Description: From the relatively cool climes of Adelaide Hills, this polished, perfumed Shiraz is a heady combo of dried rose petals, red and black berries, cedar shavings and a myriad dried herbs and spices. There's a good lick of oak influence here, too. The palate shows a touch of heat from the alcohol, but overall it's medium in weight and made with restraint. There's a lovely, silky texture to the fruit and a savory nuance on the finish.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Shaw and Smith 2016 Shiraz (Adelaide Hills)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Description: There's a lot going on in this bottling, starting with aromas of tart boysenberry syrup, crushed purple flowers and a hint of bubblegum. The palate is dense, with rich blackberry flavors, almost peppery tannins and a pinpoint acidity, proving fruity and candied yet also refreshing.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: McClean 2018 One Last Syrah (Paso Robles)

Description: From the sunny South Aussie Coonawarra region, this is a Shiraz you could cut with a knife. It needs a decanter if drinking young but with air it quickly offers ripe berry fruit, menthol and oak spice. Powerful, chewy tannins envelop the plush, tangy fruit on the palate. Ideally, this needs more time for those tannins to settle into the wine. Drink 2022–2030.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Di Giorgio Family Wines 2016 Shiraz (Coonawarra)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: This wine is rounded with 20% Cabernet Sauvignon and 5% Viognier, with fruit from Ciel du Cheval, Klipsun and a splash from Boushey. Aromas of blue fruit, dried herbs, raspberry compote and milk are followed by ripe fruit flavors. The variety's hedonism is on display.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Sparkman 2016 Ruckus Syrah (Red Mountain)

Description: Reductive and oak-driven, this wine is thick and concentrated in plum, garrigue, gamy meat and black olive. Being 100% varietal, it speaks to the power and weight of the grape in a warm year and from a warm site, taking on a velvety smoothness on the finish.                      Virginie Boone
Name: Patland 2017 10th Anniversary Syrah (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Colli della Toscana Centrale, Tuscany, Italy
Description: Made from organically farmed Syrah, this opens with black-skinned berry, ground pepper and cedar aromas. The solid, concentrated palate offers black currant, tobacco and a whiff of smoke alongside chewy tannins. Drink through 2026.                      Kerin O’Keefe
Name: Fontodi 2017 Case Via Syrah (Colli della Toscana Centrale)

Description: This vintage is quite young and closed at the moment. After lots of swirling and time in glass it opens somewhat, revealing fresh black cherry, blueberry, licorice and sweet spices. The oak is prominent, and, as in previous years, a little on the soapy side. Things improve significantly on the palate, however, where a lift of refreshing acidity adds tang to the already fresh fruit. The tannins are fine and chalky, and a line of crushed Mediterranean herbs makes its way to the finish. Drink 2022–2035.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Leeuwin Estate 2018 Siblings Shiraz (Margaret River)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Fruit for this wine comes from Candy Mountain Vineyard, which recently became its own subappellation of the valley. Aromas of earth, raspberry and spice aromas lead to flavors that show a pleasing sense of elegance. It's a pretty offering of this variety.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Succession 2018 Syrah (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Hunter Valley, New South Wales, Australia
Description: The 2017 was a hot vintage in the Hunter Valley and even though alcohol is restrained, the warmth of the season is still felt in this wine. The nose is initially reductive so decant if drinking now. With air, notes of ripe blueberry, cherry, plum, dried rose and peppery spice make their way out. The palate is powerful yet focused, with taut, spicy, somewhat austere tannins alongside heaps of acidity and chalky texture. There's a slight bitterness on the finish. This needs more time in bottle to relax its iron grip. Drink 2022–2035.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Brokenwood 2017 Graveyard Vineyard Shiraz (Hunter Valley)

Description: From close planted vines on terra rossa soil, this clearly Rhône-inspired wine is a little reductive at first, but the barnyard notes blow off with time, replaced with ripe plum, berry, dried mint, oregano and tar. The oak is present but softly spoken. In the mouth, it shows a lovely tang of acidity and juicy fruit, but the tannins are on the lean and mean side, drying at the finish. Overall, this feels unforced and allowed to express both fruit and site. It's drinking well now but should keep until 2025.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Terre à Terre 2015 Crayères Vineyard Shiraz (Wrattonbully)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Aromas of cough medicine, smoke, green herb, smoked meat and eucalyptus are followed by fruit flavors that seem surprisingly light, especially considering the labeled alcohol. It's hard to tell where it's all is going.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Alleromb 2017 Scarline Vineyard Syrah (Columbia Valley (WA))

Description: This vintage is both sweetly fruited and quite oaky. Plums, black cherries, mocha, licorice and black olives are all overlaid by spicy barrel notes. In the mouth, the fruit is silky and juicy against the talc-like tannins. Medium in weight and with plenty of class, this needs time for the oak to find its way to the wings. Drink now–2028.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Leeuwin Estate 2017 Art Series Shiraz (Margaret River)

Description: This is a high octane McLaren Vale Shiraz, with a polished sheen that some will dig and others will run from. There's lots of plump plum and brambly berry aromas, with cloves and violets all blanketed in a dusting polish sheen. There's also nicely textured, leathery tannins that balance the tangy, ripe fruit. The oak is a bit drying and bitter, and the alcohol, at nearly 16%, is prominent.                      Christina Pickard
Designation: The Border Crossing 100% Basket Pressed Old Vines
Name: Tait Wines 2015 The Border Crossing 100% Basket Pressed Old Vines Shiraz (McLaren Vale)

Description: Despite being from one of the coolest subregions in McLaren Vale, Blewitt Springs, this is a high octane Shiraz. It opens with vibrant aromas of red and black berries, peppery, savory spice and undertones of graphite and licorice. There's a fair amount of oak influence visible. The tannins on the full-bodied palate are angular and pinching in a way that feels a little disjointed. There's some alcohol heat, too. Nevertheless, big red lovers will find charm amidst the power.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Cockfighter's Ghost 2016 Single Vineyard Shiraz (McLaren Vale)

Description: This is a high octane McLaren Vale Shiraz, with a polished sheen that some will dig and others will run from. There's lots of plump plum and brambly berry aromas, with cloves and violets all blanketed in a dusting polish sheen. There's also nicely textured, leathery tannins that balance the tangy, ripe fruit. The oak is a bit drying and bitter, and the alcohol, at nearly 16%, is prominent.                      Christina Pickard
Designation: The Border Crossing 100% Basket Pressed Old Vines
Name: Tait Wines 2015 The Border Crossing 100% Basket Pressed Old Vines Shiraz (McLaren Vale)

Description: Despite being from one of the coolest subregions in McLaren Vale, Blewitt Springs, this is a high octane Shiraz. It opens with vibrant aromas of red and black berries, peppery, savory spice and undertones of graphite and licorice. There's a fair amount of oak influence visible. The tannins on the full-bodied palate are angular and pinching in a way that feels a little disjointed. There's some alcohol heat, too. Nevertheless, big red lovers will find charm amidst the power.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Cockfighter's Ghost 2016 Single Vineyard Shiraz (McLaren Vale)

Appellation: Hunter Valley, New South Wales, Australia
Description: The 2017 was the hottest vintage on record in the Hunter Valley and the warmth shows here in the form of ripe cherry and blueberry fruit wound in cola-like oak. As it unravels in glass, secondary notes of violets and warm stones reveal themselves. The fruit on the palate is juicy yet plush, and tannins are nicely textured.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Audrey Wilkinson 2017 Winemakers Selection Shiraz (Hunter Valley)

Description: This is a thick, plummy and jammy red wine, meaty and tannic, with a heft and breadth across the palate. Leather, blueberry and a touch of game fill the glass with intensity and lasting power.                      Virginie Boone
Name: Chateau St. Jean 2016 Reserve Syrah (Sonoma County)

Description: From the Riverina region, this Shiraz is all plump berries, spice and chocolate. Some cola-like oak is there, too, but is pretty well tucked away. There's some heat from the alcohol on the palate, as well as ripe, plush fruit and more-present barrel influence. Nevertheless, this is a rich, succulent wine, with plenty of curbside appeal.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Nugan Family Estates 2016 Scruffy's Single Vineyard Shiraz (Riverina)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Crisp boysenberry fruit and a lush flash of caramel show on the nose of this bottling, which remains lively despite its advanced age. The tannins are still tight on the palate, where blackberry-jam flavors arise.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Cooper-Garrod 2014 Test Pilot F-104 Starfighter Syrah (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Crisp boysenberry fruit and a lush flash of caramel show on the nose of this bottling, which remains lively despite its advanced age. The tannins are still tight on the palate, where blackberry-jam flavors arise.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Cooper-Garrod 2014 Test Pilot F-104 Starfighter Syrah (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Description: This ticks the South Aussie Shiraz boxes via plush, velvety red and black fruit, cloves, cola-like oak and leathery tannins. It's rich, spicy and a little on the woody side but overall makes for a solid wintertime sipper.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Thorn Clarke 2017 Eden Trail Shiraz (Eden Valley)

Description: High-toned acidity contrasts against firm, powerful tannin in this vineyard-designate, aged 20 months in both French and American oak. Raspberry and strawberry fruit is seasoned with black pepper and clove.                      Virginie Boone
Name: Hagafen 2018 Wieruszowski Vineyard Syrah (Coombsville)

Description: The plum and berry fruit on the nose is on the stewed side in this broad shouldered Shiraz. The oak feels mealy and cola-like, backed by chocolate, mint and olive. The powerful palate is dominated by chewy, drying tannins but plush, plummy fruit and savory spice peek through the cracks.                      Christina Pickard
Name: D'Arenberg 2017 The Love Grass Shiraz (McLaren Vale)

Description: This is a rich wine, with a slightly synthetic-seeming aromatic lift of red currants, cherries, violets and a soapy, potpourri note. There's lovely lift of acidity on the palate—welcome amidst the heavy oak and fruit.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Maxwell 2017 Silver Hammer Shiraz (McLaren Vale)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Fruit for this wine comes from Quintessence Vineyard. The aromas pop, with notes of raspberry and Craisins. It's lighter than the aromas might suggest, front loaded and pulling up on the finish. It seems quite overripe, with the fruit dried out.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Succession 2018 Reserve Syrah (Red Mountain)

Description: A strong, forced char and cedar character in the aromas and flavors limit the appeal of this one-dimensional and very full-bodied wine. It is oaky, dry and moderately tannic.                      Jim Gordon
Name: Tehachapi 2017 Reserve Syrah (California)

Description: This is a straightforward medium-to-full bodied Shiraz that offers notes of sour cherries, grape jelly and faint oak spice. The palate is thin and a little unharmonious, with bulky, drying tannins blanketing the berry fruit.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Mad Fish 2016 Shiraz (Western Australia)

Description: At over seven years of age, there's still plenty of freshness in this wine. There's also a bit of a sweaty funk on the nose, but it doesn't overpower the cherry and soft spice aromas. The palate is a touch sour and synthetic, with chewy, drying, rather unforgiving tannins, and balance is never quite reached.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Farmer's Leap 2013 Shiraz (Padthaway)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: The aromas offer notes of funk, ash, herb and barrel spice. The flavors are lighter in style, with the concentration seeming a bit dilute. Barrel flavors play a significant role.                      Sean P. Sullivan
Name: Gordon Estate 2016 Estate Grown Syrah (Columbia Valley (WA))

Description: Ripe, somewhat confected fruit, sweet spice and vanilla aromas in this wine lead to a palate that feels disjointed, as though the oak, fruit and tannins are on opposite sides of the room. It lacks cohesion and varietal distinction.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Fowles Wine 2017 Farm To Table Shiraz (Victoria)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Joey Tensley's expertise in rich Syrahs makes a perfect partner to this cool-climate site in the Sta. Rita Hills. Intense aromas of peppercorn, roast lamb, tar and elderberry coulis lead into a dense, viscous and yet enlivening palate, loaded with flavors of spicy cracked pepper and beef yakitori in a blackberry dipping sauce. It only grows more intense with time. Drink now through 2038.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Tensley 2018 Turner Vineyard Syrah (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Almost opaque in the glass, this powerful bottling, which includes 2% each of Grenache and Viognier and was aged in mostly new French oak for 23 months and begins with aromas of cassis, cola, black pepper and violet. It's silky smooth on the palate at first, before the tannins stand up to balance the rich flavors of cassis, espresso bean, cola and charred meat, with waves of purple-flower flavors that won't stop. Drink now through 2037.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Clos Solène 2017 Hommage A Nos Pairs Reserve Syrah (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Strong aromas of cola, roasted meat, incense, black currant and cracked peppercorn kick off this bottling, which includes 1% each of Roussanne and Viognier. A rich black-currant flavor hits the palate first, then come waves of peppercorn and cocoa, all wrapped in lush yet tense tannins. Drink through 2038.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Denner 2018 Dirt Worshipper Syrah (Central Coast)

Appellation: Adelaida District, Central Coast, California, US
Description: A beautiful and dense shade of dark purple, this intense bottling begins with aromas of elderberry jam and black-currant pie that demand repeated returns on the nose. It's soft and lushly texture on the palate, where cassis, charred wood and peppercorn flavors prove very complex and compelling.                      Matt Kettmann
Designation: Either Side of the Hill Glenrose Vineyard
Name: Paix Sur Terre 2018 Either Side of the Hill Glenrose Vineyard Syrah (Adelaida District)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Description: This is a cooler-climate Syrah done with the light touch of a Pinot Noir master. The nose is extremely peppery, reminiscent of a tour through a Tellicherry peppercorn factory, yet with tart cranberry, rust and soil elements as well. The palate is immensely grippy with more white pepper as well as charcoal and brisk red-fruit flavors. It will also cellar very well.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Chanin 2018 Schock Family Vineyard Syrah (Santa Barbara County)

Description: Incredibly dark in color and intense in aromas, this bottling is lush with concentrated blackberry, black currant, charred wood and a hint of coffee on the nose. On the palate, firm yet polished tannins uphold dense flavors of black cherry, roasted black currant and plum, cola, espresso bean and cracked pepper. Acid washes into the finish.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Herman Story 2018 Nuts & Bolts Syrah (California)

Description: If one can get past the heavy bottle in the age of climate change, this is a stellar vintage of Craggy's Range's premium Hawkes Bay Syrah. It's got a nose you could dive into and swim around in the freshly squeezed blackberry and currant fruit, cracked pepper, cocoa nibs, graphite and warm stone mineral notes. There's plenty of oak here, too, but it should integrate nicely into the wine with time. In the mouth, the fruit continues on a juicy journey, gripped by powerful, fine tannins and interlaced with oodles of dried herbs and spices. This should cellar beautifully. Drink now with decanter and protein at hand until 2040.                      Christina Pickard
Name: Craggy Range 2016 Le Sol Gimblett Gravels Syrah (Hawke's Bay)

Appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Crumpled hibiscus, white-pepper, black-raspberry and dried lamb aromas show on this bottling from a vineyard that sits between the Chalone and Mt. Harlan appellations. The floral aspects pop first on the palate, then come richer waves of elderberry and mulberry, with pepper spice lasting long into the finish.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Big Basin 2016 Coastview Vineyard Syrah (Monterey County)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Slightly lighter in the glass than other Syrahs, this bottling is immensely savory, showing cracked pepper, crushed rocks, dried blackberry and black plum on a well-focused nose. It's very fresh on the palate, with snappy black raspberry and a dusting of white pepper, with warming hints of baking spice into the finish.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Ex Post Facto 2018 Syrah (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Crumpled lavender, tart black plum and a hint of teriyaki show on the nose of this bottling from the Tensley family's home vineyard. Savory flavors of roasted beef, crusted in rosemary and lavender, meet with cassis and are wrapped in firm tannins on the palate.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Tensley 2018 Tensley Vineyard Syrah (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Description: One of the annual magnum-only releases from Joey Tensley, this one, named after his niece, blends syrah from Rodney's and Colson Canyon vineyards with 25% Grenache from the latter as well. Rich black-plum, cola, smoked beef and pepper aromas hit all the right notes on the nose, while the palate offers hearty cassis and sarsaparilla spice. Drink 2022–2038.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Tensley 2018 BMT Syrah (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Named for winemaker Joey Tensley's son, Oliver Gunnar Tensley, this magnum bottling combines from the Tensley, Colson Canyon and Thompson vineyards. The nose is intense with pepper, violets and açai aromas, leading into a palate that is deep and rich with cassis and cracked pepper, yet leveled by tons of acidity. Drink 2022–2040.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Tensley 2018 OGT Syrah (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Description: Smoky aromas of mesquite meet with smoked lamb shank and blackberry compote on the nose of this heavy-duty bottling. More smoked meats and rich cassis are lifted by cracked peppercorns and lush caramel on the palate, where the oak elements are powerful but delicious.                      Matt Kettmann
Name: Herman Story 2017 Bien Nacido Vineyard Syrah (Santa Maria Valley)
